article.title: Properties of the circumgalactic medium in simulations compared to observations

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows various properties of a simulated galaxy at z=0. What is the approximate virial radius (r_vir) of this galaxy?
choices: 20 kpc
90 kpc
180 kpc
360 kpc

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the relationship between the total gas mass forming the CGM and the stellar mass of simulated central galaxies. What trend is observed for the redshift range z=0-2?
choices: The total CGM gas mass decreases with increasing stellar mass.
The relationship between total CGM gas mass and stellar mass is unclear.
The total CGM gas mass remains roughly constant across the redshift range.
The total CGM gas mass increases with increasing stellar mass, with larger dispersions for M* < 10^10 M.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents the oxygen mass in different components (CGM, ISM, stars) as a function of stellar mass. What is the main trend observed for the fraction of oxygen mass (f_oxy) stored in stars?
choices: f_oxy decreases with increasing stellar mass.
f_oxy remains constant across different stellar masses.
f_oxy is consistently higher at z=0 compared to higher redshifts.
f_oxy increases with increasing stellar mass, reaching ~0.8 for M* ~ 10^10 M at z=2.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the fraction of gas mass, oxygen mass, and OVI mass in different CGM phases (cool, warm, hot) as a function of stellar mass. At z=0, which phase dominates the total CGM mass for massive galaxies (M* > 10^10 M)?
choices: Cool phase
Warm/Hot phase
The contribution from all phases is roughly equal.
The figure doesn't provide information about the dominant phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares simulated and observed X-ray luminosities (0.5-2 keV) for the most massive galaxies.  What can be concluded about the agreement between simulated and observed values?
choices: Simulated values are significantly lower than observed values.
Simulated values are generally in a comparable range to observed values, showing better agreement in the outer annulus.
Simulated values are significantly higher than observed values.
Simulated and observed values show no clear relationship.
